stem: A 32-year-old client with schizophrenia was started on Haloperidol 4 days ago. Based on the documentation in the Neuromuscular & Autonomic Stability Log, which complication is the client most likely experiencing?

tabs.title: Neuromuscular Exam
tabs.content: Current: Muscles are extremely stiff and resistant to passive movement ('Lead-pipe rigidity'). No rhythmic twitching noted. Reflexes are 1+ (Sluggish/Diminished).

tabs.title: Vital Signs & Autonomic
tabs.content:
Vitals: Temp 104.2Â°F, BP 184/108 (Labile), HR 128.
Skin: Profuse diaphoresis.
Bowels: Bowel sounds are absent in all four quadrants.

rationale.correct: This is **Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) (a1)**. NMS is a life-threatening reaction to dopamine-blocking antipsychotics (like Haloperidol). The hallmark cues that distinguish it from Serotonin Syndrome are the **'Lead-pipe rigidity'** (stiffness), **hyporeflexia** (1+ reflexes), and massive elevation of **CK** (35,000) due to intense muscle contraction and breakdown. The extremely high fever (104.2) and 'labile' (fluctuating) blood pressure are also classic autonomic signs.
clinicalPearls: Priority: 1. Stop the antipsychotic. 2. Aggressive cooling. 3. Administer Dantrolene or Bromocriptine.
High CK leads to a secondary risk of AKI (Rhabdomyolysis).

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Serotonin Syndrome (a2) because of the high fever.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the **Muscle Tone**. If the patient is stiff as a board (Lead-pipe), it's NMS. If the patient is twitching/jerking (Myoclonus) with hyperactive bowels, it's Serotonin Syndrome.
